questions.text: A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8 weeks of pregnancy is called _____.
questions.solution:
A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8th week of pregnancy is called Chadwick’s sign or Jacquemier’s sign. The discoloration is due to local vascular congestion.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text:
A 23-year-old primigravida at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension 2 weeks back. Lab values are as follows. Which of the following other laboratory findings would be most likely seen in this patient?

Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
Blood glucose and cholesterol: Normal
Peripheral smear: Hemolytic red blood cells
questions.solution:
The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, suggests a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Elevated aspartate transaminase (AST) would be most likely seen in this patient with HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is an acronym that stands for: 

  • Hemolysis
  • Elevated Liver enzymes 
  • Low Platelets

Microangiopathic hemolysis manifests as:

  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels (Option B)
  • Reduced haptoglobin levels
  • Schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis on peripheral blood smear

Elevation of AST and ALT (liver enzymes) levels occurs due to periportal hemorrhagic necrosis in the liver. Furthermore, hemorrhagic infarcts can extend to form a subcapsular hematoma that stretches the Glisson capsule. This results in characteristic epigastric/right quadrant pain and tenderness. It can be diagnosed using a CT or MRI. 

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema. 

Option A: Markedly elevated bilirubin levels are not likely seen in HELLP syndrome which characteristically does not present with marked hepatic dysfunction unlike acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Patients with acute fatty liver of pregnancy are likely to present with marked elevations of AST and bilirubin, hypoglycemia and hypocholesterolemia.

The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:

Disorders  HELLP syndrome Obstetric cholestasis Acute fatty liver of pregnancy Viral hepatitis
Onset in pregnancy Mid to late Late Late Variable
Differentiating features        - Pruritus  (elevated serum bile acids) Signs of liver failure  Fever
AST (U/L)  ≤300  ≤200 200-800 2000+
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 1-4 1-5 4-10 5-20
Platelets ↓↓  Normal ↓↓  ↓
Fibrinogen Normal Normal ↓↓↓ Normal
D-dimer ↑ Normal ↑ Normal
Prothrombin time Normal Normal ↑↑  ↑
Hemolysis  ↑↑ No ↑↑↑  No

questions.text: The abnormality noted in the given image of placenta is

choices.text: The cord is attached to the membranes
Fetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery
A small lobe of placenta lies seperate from main part

questions.solution:
The image depicts the battledore placenta in which the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

In the Battledore placenta, the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a Previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

Other options:

Option A: Velamentous placenta - the cord is attached to the membranes and blood vessels pass through the membrane and then the placenta to supply it.

Option B: Circumvallate placenta - the fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery which is made of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

Option D: Succenturiate placenta - one or small lobes of the placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complete perineal tear that occurred during delivery two days back. When is the ideal time to repair this tear?
questions.solution:
In case of a complete perineal tear presenting 24 hours after the injury, the optimum time for operative repair is after 3-6 months post-delivery.

The best time of repair is, however, within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, then the better option is to do it 3-6 months after delivery.

If operated early, healing with the first intention might be affected while later repairs can lead to dense scar tissue which might cause difficulties while operating. 

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: Used for delivery in a platypelloid pelvis
Most commonly used for rotational delivery
Most commonly used forceps in outlet delivery
It is used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech

questions.solution:
The image shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of breech.

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

It maybe applied electively or when the Mauriceau manoeuvre cannot be accomplished easily.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following increases during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Fibrinogen increases during pregnancy.

All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factor 11,13. Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state.

Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13) and fibrinogen levels are also increased.
  • The viscosity of blood doesn’t increase since plasma volume increases more in comparison to red cell volume, it merely decreases whole blood viscosity.
  • Clotting time is unaffected.
  • The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and women are asymptomatic).
  • Fibrinolytic activity remains depressed till about 15 minutess after pregnancy

questions.text: A 26 year old primigravida presents with labour pains at 39 weeks of gestation. Her cervix is 3 cm dilated and she fails to enter active phase of labor even after 20 hours. What is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest that the patient is in prolonged latent phase of labor and the preferred treatment is bed rest.

A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is termed as prolonged latent phase of labor. Bed rest is the preferred treatment unless there is any indication for expediting the delivery.

Prolonged latent phase is not an indication for caesarean section.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

questions.text: Major postpartum haemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than _____ mL of blood after completion of third stage of labour in vaginal delivery.
questions.solution:
Major postpartum haemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than 1000 mL of blood after completion of third stage of labour (in vaginal delivery).

Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery).

PPH is blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following cesarean section.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be, minor (<1L) or major (>1L). Major is further subdivided into moderate (1L-2L) and severe (>2L).

Recent Update :

PPH is classically defined by the volume of blood loss. But this definition will soon become obsolete as the bleeding may not be visible externally, or the blood in collection devices may be mixed with amniotic fluid.

In 2017, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists revised their definition of PPH to

  • Cumulative blood loss of ≥1000 mL or 
  • Bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of the birth process (regardless of the route of delivery).

questions.text: The target gene of SRY which favors testis differentiation is:
questions.solution:
SOX9 is the target gene for SRY which favors testis differentiation.

The sex of the fetus is determined by the Y chromosome (a short arm of chromosome Y, Yp11) which contains SRY (Sex determining region on Y) gene that encodes for the protein that determines the fate of rudimentary sexual organs.

SRY protein is the testis determining factor, Under whose influence, male development occurs. The target gene for SRY which favors testis differentiation is SOX9.

If SRY is absent, female development is established. Genes that favor ovary differentiation are WnT4, Rspo, DAX1.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with an ultrasound report suggesting a fetus in breech position with hyperextended neck. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a fetus with a hyperextended neck indicates that the fetus is in a stargazing position at term. The next best step in the management is to terminate by Cesarean section.

This hyperextension makes vaginal delivery and ECV dangerous as they can result in fetal cervical spine injury. And thus, the stargazing position is an indication for a Cesarean section.

Cesarean delivery of the breech fetus is indicated in the following:

  • Large fetus: >3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

Note: Flying fetus is a term used when the fetus is in a transverse lie with a hyperextended neck.

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida had a pre-pregnancy BMI of 18 kg/msq. What is the recommended weight gain during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given case is underweight (BMI< 18.5) and the recommended weight gain for her among the given options would be 13-18 kg.

Ideally weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy body mass index (BMI) level.

Related Pearl: Recommendation for total weight gain during pregnancy by pre-pregnancy BMI

Category (BMI) Total weight gain range [kg(lb)]
Underweight (<18.5) 12.5 - 18 (28-40 lb)
Normal weight (BMI 18.5-24.9) 11.5 - 16 (25-35 lb)
Overweight (BMI 25-29.9) 7 – 11.5 (15-25 lb)
Obese (BMI more than equal to 30) 5 - 9.1 (11-20 lb)

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2A1, presents with heavy vaginal bleeding with cramp-like abdominal pain at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to the period of gestation and  active vaginal bleeding is noted with an open internal os. USG reveals absent fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and examination findings of active vaginal bleeding and open internal os, with the uterine size corresponding to the period of gestation, is suggestive of inevitable abortion.

Inevitable abortion is a type of abortion where the abortive process has progressed to a state where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Clinical features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding as compared to threatened abortion.
  • Aggravated lower abdominal colicky pain
  • Uterine size corresponds to or may be smaller than the period of gestation
  • On examination, dilated internal os through which the products of conception are visualized and felt but has not begun to expel out ( unlike incomplete abortion )
  • USG examination shows absent fetal cardiac activity.

Risk factors:

  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes 
  • Amniocentesis
  • Prior second-trimester delivery
  • Tobacco use
  • Fetal surgery.

Management:

  • IV Methergine is indicated if there is excessive bleeding when the cervix is dilated and uterine size is. <12 weeks.
  • Before 12 weeks:
    • Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage
    • Alternatively, suction and evacuation.
  • After 12 weeks:
    • Oxytocin drip, 10 units in 500mL of NS at 40-60 drips per minute
    • The separated placenta is removed by ovum forceps and digital separation is indicated if the placenta is not separated.

A representation of various types of abortions is given below:

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient was evaluated for recurrent pregnancy loss. Her hysterosalpingogram and sonography revealed a bicornuate uterus. Defect in the development of which of the following structures leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The defect in the development of the paramesonephric duct (Mullerian duct) can lead to a bicornuate uterus. It is caused by the incomplete fusion of the Mullerian ducts.

The derivatives of the paramesonephric duct (Mullerian duct) in females:

  • Fallopian tubes
  • Uterus and cervix
  • Upper part of vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with a painful vulvar lesion. On examination, there is an exophytic and ulcerative vulvar mass. It is about 4 cm in diameter and there are no palpable inguinal lymph nodes. Incisional biopsy reveals a poorly differentiated invasive vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Which among the following is false?

choices.text: Labia minora is the most common site
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Groin node status is the best prognostic predictor
Spread through vascular route is rare

questions.solution:
Labia minora is the most common site is a false statement. The most common site of vulvar cancer is labia majora.

Vulval cancer is most common in elderly females in the 6th or 7th decade. In young women, human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and smoking can increase the risk of vulval cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulvar cancer.

Clinically, patients present with pruritus, vulval swelling, lump, or ulcer. Lesions are seen commonly in labia majora. The clitoris and perineal region can also be involved. Ulcers can bleed and cause offensive discharge. Inguinal lymph nodes may or may not be palpable.

First lymph node involved: Superficial inguinal lymph node > Deep inguinal lymph node > Femoral group of lymph nodes. The vascular route of spread is rare in vulvar cancer. Groin node status is the best prognostic predictor.

Sentinel lymph node mapping is useful in vulval cancer. It is the lymph node that receives the drainage directly from the primary tumor. Removal of the sentinel lymph node helps to avoid unnecessary dissection of other nodes. This can be achieved by lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy before or during surgery.

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient in her second trimester came with complaints of bleeding. She had a prior Cesarean section. Ultrasound showed a placental abnormality that corresponds to the illustration given below. The following placental abnormality is due to the absence or improper development of ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta percreta. The abnormality is due to the partial or total absence of decidua basalis.

Decidua is the modified endometrium of pregnancy. It is classified into three parts as follows:

  • Decidua basalis is the part deeper into the developing blastocyst.
  • Decidua capsularis: part surrounding enlarging blastocyst and separating the conceptus and the uterine cavity.
  • Decidua parietalis: part lining the rest of the uterine cavity.

The below image shows the parts of the decidua.

The pathology in this condition is that the decidua basalis is absent and the Nitabuch layer is imperfectly developed.

When the villi are attached to the myometrium, it is known as placenta accreta whereas, in placenta increta, the myometrium is invaded by the villi. In placenta percreta, there is the penetration of villi through the serosa and the myometrium.

Risk factors include a co-existing previa and previous history of Cesarean section. Hemorrhage is the most common presentation in the first and second trimesters.

Treatment is a Cesarian section followed by hysterectomy.

The below image shows the placenta accreta, increta and percreta.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the placental separation method shown in the image below:

choices.text: It is commonly known as Schultz method
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva
It is an abnormal method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Mathews-Duncan method of placental separation where the maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labour. There are two normal mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

Schultze method:

  • The separation begins at the centre of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at vulva.
  • The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clot.
  • Bleeding does not occur until the placenta is completely extruded.

Mathews-Duncan method:

  • The separation of the placenta begins at the peripheral edge of the placenta. Hence, the maternal surface appears first.
  • The blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall, and escapes out from the vagina. There is no formation of retroplacental clot and the bleeding is profuse in this method of placental separation.
  • It is much less common than Schultze method.

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Signs of placental separation: 

  • The uterus becomes globular, firm and ballottable (earliest sign to appear).
  • Schroeder's sign: Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it. 
  • Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
  • Kustner's sign: On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no longer recedes.
  • A sudden gush of blood
  • Permanent lengthening of the cord.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 60-year-old grand multipara, you notice the entire uterus lying outside the introitus. What degree of uterine descent will you assign to the clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The entire uterus is lying outside the introitus in fourth-degree uterine prolapse or procidentia.

Prolapse is a condition commonly seen in elderly menopausal women. It occurs due to the atonicity of the pelvic floor muscles and the ligaments that support the female genital tract. 

The degrees of prolapse are as follows:

  • The descent of the cervix into the vagina is first-degree prolapse.
  • When the cervix descends to the level of the vulva, it is second-degree prolapse. 
  • In third-degree prolapse, there is a protrusion of the cervix outside the vaginal orifice. 
  • Procidentia or fourth-degree prolapse is one in which the whole of the uterus protrudes outside the vulva. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: You advise your pregnant patient with regard to anaemia and inform her about the anaemia mukt bharat scheme. The correct information regarding the iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets during pregnancy, under this scheme, would be :

choices.text: A single IFA tablet will contain 400mcg of folic acid
The IFA tablets will be blue in colour
The patient needs to start taking IFA tablets from the first month of conception
The IFA tablet needs to be taken once daily while lactating

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme, pregnant women and lactating women (in the first 6 months) need to take the iron and folic acid tablet (IFA) tablet once daily.

Pregnant women, under this scheme, are given IFA tablets, which are :

  • Red in colour (option B)
  • Contain 60 mg of elemental iron and 500mcg of folic acid (option A)
  • Taken once daily from the 4th month of pregnancy for a period of 180 days (option C)
  • Taken by lactating mothers, in the same dose and once daily for a period of 6 months postpartum.

All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 500 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with episodes of a sudden sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating, palpitations, and anxiety. What is the most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a postmenopausal woman. Estrogen therapy is found to be the most effective to treat it.

Hot flushes are episodes of vasodilation affecting the face and the neck. The episode lasts for 2–5 min each. These are followed by severe sweating, palpitations, anxiety, and anginal pains may be felt. Multiple episodes occur during the day, but are more severe at night and can disturb sleep. Sometimes they can be preceded by headaches.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is only indicated for the treatment of

  • vasomotor symptoms
  • osteoporosis (prevention and treatment)
  • vaginal atrophy
  • urethral syndrome
  • dyspareunia

Estrogen can be given as oral estrogen formulations, transdermal patches, topical gel, or intravaginal formulations. For Dyspareunia, urethral syndrome, and senile vaginitis local estrogen cream is preferred over oral therapy. Short-term therapy is recommended for vasomotor symptoms whereas osteoporosis requires long-term therapy. Estrogen should be given in the smallest effective dose for the shortest duration possible. 

 Other treatments: 

Hormonal Non-Hormonal Non-prescriptive

Estrogen therapy (Most effective)

Progestin

Combination preparations

Tibolone

Clonidine 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like Fluoxetine)

selective norepinephrine- reuptake inhibitor(like desvenlafaxine)

Gabapentin

Vitamin E

Soya 

Isoflavones

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as these may enlarge in size.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with infertility underwent semen analysis. Results show a sperm concentration of 18 million/ml, pH- 7.5, and volume- 2 ml. No agglutination is seen. Morphology shows 10% normal forms and 20% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given semen analysis point towards a diagnosis of asthenospermia as only 20% of the sperms are motile. Normally, 32% of sperm should be motile.

Other options:

Option A: Azoospermia - Absence of sperm in semen

Option C: Normospermia - Sperm concentration of > 15 million/ml

Option D: Oligospermia- Sperm concentration of < 15 million/ml 

Note: 

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: A primigravida comes to you for her first antenatal visit. You discover on routine investigations that her blood group is B negative while her husbands' is B positive. You reassure her and explain to her the role of anti D injections in the prevention of red cell alloimmunization pevention. Which of the following is true about anti D immunoprophylaxis:

choices.text: Can be administered IM or IV depending on the preparation
The half life of anti D is 60 days
It is given 72 hrs postpartum irrespective of the baby's blood group
300 mcg of anti D can neutralize 20 ml of fetal red blood cells

questions.solution:
Anti-D immune globulin can be administered via IM/IV route depending on the preparation.

Anti-D immune globulin is derived from the plasma of individuals who have a high titer of these antibodies. Formulations that are prepared by cold ethanol fractionation and ultrafiltration contain plasma proteins that could result in anaphylaxis if given intravenously. Thus, they must be administered intramuscularly. However, formulations prepared by ion exchange chromatography may be administered either intramuscularly or intravenously.

Other options:

Option B: The half-life of anti-D is 16-24 days due to which it is usually administered in the third trimester and following delivery.

Option C: Anti-D is given to an unsensitized mother at 28 weeks and then again postpartum. The postpartum dose has to be given within 72 hrs of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive.

Option D: 300 micrograms of Anti D can neutralize 15 ml of fetal RBCs or 30 ml of fetal whole blood. If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of Rh-immune globulin is calculated as 10 μg for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

questions.text: Identify the given sign on a uterine artery doppler seen at 22 weeks of gestation in a pregnant woman.
questions.solution:
The given red arrow in the doppler image points to the diastolic notch in a uterine artery doppler.

The uterine artery doppler waveform in pregnant women is characterized by high diastolic flow velocities and markedly turbulent flow. Diastolic notch is present in uterine artery flow between 22 and 24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester). In normal pregnant women, the diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks.

Persistence of the notch beyond 24 weeks of gestation is associated with the development of gestational hypertension and IUGR. However, this finding is not used in clinical practice as it has a poor predictive value.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with pain in her left breast. She has had difficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals that her left breast is warm, red, swollen, and painful to palpation. Her temperature is 38.3 degrees and the WBC count is 13000/mm3. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain, redness, warmth, and tenderness in the breast, along with fever and leucocytosis is suggestive of mastitis. Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers.

Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the bacteria residing in the infant's nose and throat. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus, which can be cultured from breast milk. The symptoms appear in the 3rd or 4th week postpartum. Predisposing factors include fissures, abrasions, or cracks in the nipple. 

The first line of treatment is dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally, 4 times a day for 10-14 days. Other beta lactamase-resistant penicillins that are recommended include cloxacillin and flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.

If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or if resistant organisms are suspected while awaiting the culture results, then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given. 

Breastfeeding should be continued. Sometimes the infant may not nurse on the inflamed breast due to engorgement and edema, which makes the areola harder to grip. Pumping alleviates this. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on the uninvolved breast. This allows let-down to commence before moving to the tender breast.

In HIV patients with mastitis or breast abscess, even in resource-poor countries, it is recommended to stop feeding from the infected breast because HIV RNA levels increase in affected breast milk. These levels return to baseline after symptoms resolve.

The first image below shows mastitis and the second image shows a breast abscess.

questions.text: Rubin's criteria is used for diagnosing:
questions.solution:
Rubin’s criteria is used to diagnose cervical pregnancy.

Rubins diagnostic criteria:

(1) cervical glands are found opposite the placental attachment site, and

(2) a portion of or the entire placenta is located below either the entrance of the uterine vessels or the peritoneal reflection on the anterior and posterior uterine surface.

The incidence of cervical pregnancies appears to be rising because of artificial reproductive techniques, especially in-vitro fertilization and embryo transfer. A risk factor unique to cervical pregnancy is a history of dilatation and curettage in a prior pregnancy.

Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:

  • Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria) Rubin's criteria (Histological criteria)
  • Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria
  • Primary abdominal: Studiford's criteria

 

Paalman and McElin Criteria:

  1. Uterine bleeding without cramping pain following a period of amenorrhea

  2. A soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus

  3. Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix

  4. A closed internal cervical os and

  5. A partially opened external cervical os.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 42 weeks 1 day of gestation is still not having labor pains. What color is the amniotic fluid likely to be in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a post-term pregnancy (>42 weeks). The amniotic fluid color in this patient is likely to be greenish-yellow.

ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks of gestation. For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery (>294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Usually, the amniotic fluid appears colorless in early pregnancy

Option C: In Rh-negative pregnancy, amniotic fluid is golden yellow.

Option D: In intrauterine death (absent fetal movements and FHS absent on doppler), a tobacco juice amniotic fluid is seen.

 

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of the tumor specimen is shown in the below image. This finding indicates which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The given image shows signet ring cells which are seen in Kruckenberg tumors.

Krukenberg tumors are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis.
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

Other options:

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma, characterized by the arrangement of large tumor cells in bunches. Lymphocytes and giant cells are seen in between the tumor cells. Infiltration of fibrous septa by lymphocytes is an important diagnostic feature.

 


Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor, which is used as a tumor marker. 

Grossly these tumors appear as yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. Microscopically, these tumors show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are seen as papillary projections composed of a central core of blood vessels and are lined by tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

 

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-containing epithelial ovarian tumor. These tumors are usually multilocular and are lined by single columnar epithelium. They are usually unilateral and are found along with a dermoid cyst or a Brenner tumor. Grossly they have a glistening surface, and the cut section reveals multiple loculi filled with mucinous contents. If the tumour ruptures, it may lead to formation of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: Which among the following is a contraindication for induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Active genital herpes is a contraindication for induction of labor. 

The fetus becomes affected by the virus shed from the cervix or lower genital tract during vaginal delivery. The risk of fetal infection is high in primary genital HSV due to high virus shedding compared to a recurrent infection. Caesarian delivery is indicated in an active primary HSV infection where the membranes are intact or recently ruptured.

Abruptio placentae, oligohydraminos and Rh-isoimmunization are indications for induction of labor.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: The maneuver shown in the image is :
questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is called modified Ritgen maneuver and it is done in delivery of head in normal labor.

  • When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum.
  • The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.
  • This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the intrauterine device shown below?

choices.text: It has silver added to the copper wire
It can be used as an emergency contraceptive
It has a lifespan of 10 years

questions.solution:
The given image shows the intrauterine contraceptive device, multi-load copper 250. It can be used for emergency contraception.

Mechanism of action:

Once placed inside the uterine cavity, the multi-load copper 250 device acts as a foreign body and induces inflammatory changes in the endometrium. Copper released from the device cause enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrium. It increases uterine contractility leading to the expulsion of the fertilized egg from the fallopian tube into the endometrium before the development of chorionic villi and ultimately, causes failure of implantation. The fertilized egg is then engulfed by the macrophages recruited due to the inflammatory changes. In addition, the device hinders the migration of the sperm.

The lifespan of multi-load copper 250 is about 3-5 years.

Other options:

Option A: Nova T has silver added to the copper wire which prolongs its lifespan to 5 years. 

Option C: Copper T 380 A (Paraguard) is effective as a contraceptive for up to 10 years, and is shown in the image below.

 Option D: Mirena IUCD contains levonorgestrel 52 mg, and is shown below

Other important intrauterine devices are progestasert having 38 mg of progesterone and levonova containing 60mg of levonorgestrel (LNG).

questions.text: An intern, while calculating Bishop score, gives a score of 2 for the position of the cervix. Which of the following inferences can you draw regarding the position of the cervix from this?
questions.solution:
The position of the cervix in the given scenario is anterior.

The modified Bishop score is a pre-induction cervical scoring system used to predict the success of induction of labor where a score >8 conveys a high likelihood for successful induction, and a score ≤6 is considered unfavorable. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, length, position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

The cervical position reflects the relationship of the cervical os to the center point of the presenting part. It is categorized as posterior, mid-position, or anterior. Fetal descent will gradually move the cervix anteriorly. The initial posterior position is given a score of 0. As the labor progresses and the cervix comes to midline it is scored as 1. Finally, when the cervix is in the anterior position, it is scored as 2.

 

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for estrogen therapy?
questions.solution:
Uterine fibroid is a contraindication for estrogen therapy as the fibroids may enlarge in size with estrogen therapy.

Contraindications for estrogen therapy:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of a thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gallbladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

 Hypertension, diabetes, and smoking are not contraindications, provided they are regularly monitored.

questions.text: A woman presents with cyclical hematuria 8 months after an emergency cesarean section was done for non-progress of labor. There is no urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Other causes of cyclical hematuria can be intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) perforation into the bladder or bladder endometriosis. True pathology can be confirmed by cystoscopy.

Treatment:

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization can close the fistula. 
  • Abdominal repair using omental or gracilis graft is done if the prolonged catheterization fails.

Methylene blue swab test:

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

Other options:

Option A: In a vesicovaginal fistula, the main complaint will be constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). It usually follows difficult childbirth. A positive methylene blue test confirms the diagnosis. 

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Option D: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: What is the cervix: corpus ratio at puberty?
questions.solution:
Cervix: corpus ratio at puberty is 1:2.

The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body(corpus) of the uterus varies with age.

Age Cervix/Corpus ratio
Before puberty

2:1
At puberty

1:2
Reproductive age 1:3 or 1:4
After menopause The whole of uterus and cervix atrophies

questions.text: Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin result in the formation of ______.
questions.solution:
Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin result in the formation of constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring.

It is usually situated at the junction of the upper and lower segment of the uterus around the neck of the fetus in cephalic presentation.

Common causes are:

  • Injudicious use of oxytocics
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • A premature attempt at instrumental delivery

Bandl's ring/Pathological retraction ring

  • It is formed in cases of obstructed labor.
  • In obstructed labor the upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates. With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.
  • The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring/Bandl's ring.

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient in her 16th week of gestation came for prenatal karyotyping since her first child is suffering from Down's syndrome. Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: Limb reduction defect is a known complication

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is amniocentesis. Limb reduction defect is not a known complication of amniocentesis, it is a complication of chorionic villous sampling. 

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications

Congenital infections

Fetal genetic disorders

Alloimmunization

Assessment of lung maturity
Complications

Fetal loss

Amniotic fluid leakage

Transvaginal spotting

 

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: The instrument shown in the given image used for ______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a manual vacuum aspiration syringe, used in manual vacuum aspiration.

It is used for early pregnancy failures or elective termination for up to 12 weeks. A Negative pressure of 660 mmHg is created and products of conception are aspirated.

This procedure takes less time and is less traumatic. It can be done on OPD basis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding. The USG revealed an endometrial thickness of 8 mm. Endometrial biopsy showed endometrial hyperplasia. Which of the following histological pattern carries the highest risk of progressing to endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Complex hyperplasia with atypia carries the highest risk of progressing to endometrial carcinoma. The risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma in complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia is 29%.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

  • Simple without atypia: glands are mildly crowded with a normal tubular shape or mild gland-shape abnormalities. Nuclei are bland.
  • Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded with architectural abnormalities such as papillary infoldings. Nuclei are bland.
  • Complex with atypia: glands are markedly crowded with papillary infoldings. Nuclei show variable atypia.
Type of hyperplasia Risk of progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1, at 8 weeks of gestation, comes to you to know the mode of delivery that will be used for her present pregnancy. In her previous pregnancy, she had undergone a Cesarean section with a classical incision for unknown indication. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Vaginal birth is contraindicated in a patient who has undergone a previous classical cesarean section.

Women who have undergone classical cesarean section, are at a high risk of scar dehiscence and uterine rupture and have lesser chances of successful vaginal birth in subsequent pregnancies. Importantly, in some women, a classical scar will rupture before labor onset, and this can happen several weeks before term.

In these patients, any form of a trial of labor is contraindicated. Vaginal birth is contraindicated, forceps/vacuum-assisted, or otherwise (option B and C).

Women who have undergone an LSCS (lower segment cesarean section) are allowed a trial of labor due to a lower risk of uterine rupture.

Risk factors for a vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) :

Low risk High risk

● Transverse incision

● Prior vaginal delivery

● Sufficient personnel and equipment

● Classical or T incision in prior cesarean

● Prior rupture

● Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa

● Inadequate facilities (most consider these high-risk factors as contraindications)

Classical Cesarean Indications:

Maternal:

  • Densely adhered bladder from previous surgery
  • Leiomyoma occupies the lower uterine segment
  • Cervical cancer
  • Massive maternal obesity
  • Placenta previa with anterior implantation

Fetal:

  • A transverse lie of a large fetus
  • Impacted shoulder
  • Multiple fetuses

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding emergency contraception?

choices.text: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception
Ulipristal 3 mg can be used for emergency contraception

questions.solution:
Ulipristal 30 mg taken within 5 days is used for emergency contraception.

Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and prevents/delays ovulation, and suppresses the endometrium thereby preventing implantation.

Emergency contraceptives act by various methods. They can make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation or prevent fertilization by altering the tubal transport of sperm and/or ova.

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, levonorgestrel 0.75 mg one tablet can be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later.

questions.text: A 45-year-old  P4L4 woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort. She also gives a history of an incomplete abortion for which she had to undergo a D&C procedure. On examination, the uterus appears to be uniformly enlarged, corresponding to a 12-week gestation. The adnexa is free. You make a diagnosis and make the patient undergo a total hysterectomy. The images below show the transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, the gross specimen, histological slide, all point to the diagnosis of adenomyosis and OCPs are not risk factors for its development.

The history of a 45 yr old multiparous woman with a history of vigorous curettage, with complaints, of AUB, along with an enlarged uterus are points in favour of a diagnosis of adenomyosis. The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

  • Aetiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM)
  • Clinical features:
    • Multiparous females >40 years
    • Most common symptom: Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
    • Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia
    • Per-Vaginal: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus (corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy)
    • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign: Tender, softened uterus
  • Diagnosis:
    • It is mainly clinical
    • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • Management of adenomyosis
    • Total Hysterectomy (Treatment of choice)
    • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD is tried in younger women

questions.text: Which among the following has a clear correlation with fetal malformation in pregestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
Increased HbA1C has a clear correlation with major fetal malformation in pregestational diabetes.

Poorly controlled diabetes pre conceptionally and in early pregnancy underlie elevated malformation risk. HbA1C reflects the quality of diabetic controll over the past three months.

BMI is an independent and more substantial risk factor for macrosomia in both diabetic and non-diabetic mothers.

BMI levels are associated with increased birthweight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestational diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI. Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increased with truncal obesity.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain and dyspareunia. She had an IUCD inserted 6 months back. On examination, there was cervical tenderness, uterine tenderness, and an adnexal mass. Ultrasound shows a tubo ovarian mass. The urine pregnancy test was negative. Which of the following statements regarding her treatment is false?

choices.text: (Cefotetan 2g IV BD + Doxycycline 100 mg oral) BD is the first-line treatment
Partners should be investigated and treated
Minimally invasive surgery is indicated if the tubo ovarian mass fails to respond to antibiotics
Remove IUCD irrespective of antibiotic response

questions.solution:
The given clinical features point to a diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). There is no need to remove IUCD if the woman responds to antibiotics; failed response for 48-72 calls for its removal.

Management of PID:

  • Rest
  • IV fluids in the presence of dehydration and vomiting
  • Analgesics once the diagnosis confirmed
  • Antibiotics: Because of the damaging effect of gonococci and chlamydia on the fallopian tubes and polymicrobial nature of the infection, it is mandatory to start antibiotic therapy at the earliest and not wait for the culture results.
  • First-line therapies: Cefoxitin (2 gm intravenously every 6 hours) or cefotetan (2 gm IV every 12 hours) plus doxycycline (100 mg orally every 12 hours).
  • Placentrex (aqueous extract of the fresh placenta) 1 mL intramuscularly daily or alternate days (total of 10 injec­tions) has multipronged anti-inflammatory action. It also causes tissue regeneration, wound healing, and has signifi­cant immunotropic action involving both humoral and cellular immunity however it is outdated and not used currently.
  • Partners should be investigated and treated.
  • Percutaneous abscess drainage (PAD) under CT/ultrasound guidance of abdominal mass and pyoperitoneum yields 50% success and reduces the need for major surgery, with its associated mortality and morbidity.

questions.text: A 28 year old G3 P2 L2 presents with Hb of 4 g % at 32 weeks. The most appropriate treatment is _____.
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

Management of anaemia in pregnancy

  • At 14-16 weeks
    • Hb>11g/dl: Prophylactic IFA tablets
    • Hb 7.1-10.9 g/dl: Therapeutic IFA tablets
    • Hb< 7g/dl: Blood transfusion
  • At 20-24 weeks
    • Hb>11g/dl: Prophylactic IFA tablets
    • Hb 9-10.9 g/dl: Therapeutic IFA tablets
    • Hb 7.1-8.9 g/dl: Iron sucrose infusion
    • Hb< 7g/dl: Blood transfusion
  • At 26-30 weeks
    • Hb>11g/dl: Prophylactic IFA tablets
    • Hb 9-10.9 g/dl: Therapeutic IFA tablets
    • Hb 7.1-8.9 g/dl: For mothers who have recieved iron sucrose infusion earlier; give 2 top up doses of iron sucrose infusion. For mothers who haven't recieved iron sucrose earlier, give 4 doses of iron sucrose infusion.
    • Hb< 7g/dl: Blood transfusion
  • At 30-34 weeks
    • Hb>11g/dl: Prophylactic IFA tablets
    • Hb 9-10.9 g/dl: Therapeutic IFA tablets
    • If Hb is still less than 9 g/dl: Blood transfusion

questions.text: A 23 yr old G2P1 woman presents at 42 weeks of gestation saying she was 2 weeks past her EDD and still not in labour. She gives a similar history in previous pregnancy. She says her mother also had a similar obstetric history of post-term pregnancy. Which of the following is not an etiological factor for post-term pregnancy  ______

choices.text: Pre-pregnancy body mass index greater than 25
Hereditary history of post-term pregnancy on maternal side

questions.solution:
Placental aromatase deficiency causes disorder of sexual development while placental sulfatase deficiency is an etiological factor for post-term pregnancy.

Etiology of post-term pregnancy

  • Wrong dates: inaccurate LMP (Most common)
  • Heredity: when mother has a history of prolonged pregnancy, the risk for the daughter to have a subsequent post-term pregnancy is significantly increased.
  • Primiparity
  • Previous prolonged pregnancy
  • Sedentary habits
  • Elderly multipara
  • Anencephaly
  • Adrenal hypoplasia
  • X- linked placental sulphatase deficiency
  • Pre-pregnancy body mass index (BMI)>25

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. On examination, there was no discharge from the cervix. Microscopy reveals the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a clue cell - an epithelial cell with a fuzzy border due to adherence of bacteria. This along with the given clinical features suggests bacterial vaginosis. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 23 yr old lady is pregnant with twins. The following sign is seen on ultrasound. Her twins are most likely to be :
questions.solution:
The above given sonographic image of the T sign is seen in a monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) gestation.

The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is thin and is T shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue in between the amniotic membranes.

Twins are separated only by a membrane created by the juxtaposed amnion of each twin.

Compare with the twin peak sign (also known as the lambda (λ) sign). It is a triangular appearance of the chorion insinuating between the layers of the inter twin membrane. It is seen in dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twin pregnancy. It is best seen in the first trimester (between 10-14 weeks).

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the emergency department with features of toxic shock syndrome. She reveals the usage of the contraceptive shown below. What is the contraceptive mainly composed of?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image is suggestive of the contraceptive sponge called Today and it contains a nonoxynol-9–impregnated polyurethane disc.

It contains a spermicidal agent and is placed against the cervix. Duration of action is for about 24 hours. Once placed, the contraceptive provides protection irrespective of the number of coital episodes.

It can lead to toxic shock syndrome if left over a long period of time. It is not as effective as other contraceptives such as condoms or diaphragms.

questions.text: What is the condition seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows conjoined twins with fusion in the pelvic region, which is known as ischiopagus.

In monochorionic monoamniotic twinning, incomplete duplication of the embryonic disc can occur. Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

Depending on the degree of incomplete separation, different types of conjoined twins can form:

  • Craniopagus: United at the head
  • Thoracopagus: United at the thorax 
  • Cephalothoracopagus: Fusion of both head and thorax
  • Omphalopagous or Xiphipagous: United anteriorly from the xiphoid to the umbilicus
  • Parapagus: Lateral fusion with two heads, sharing a single thorax, abdomen, and pelvis (most common)
  • Ischiopagus: United at the pelvis 
  • Pygopagus: United in the sacral region
  • Heteropagous: Asymmetric forms

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried girl comes to the gynecology OPD for vaccination against cervical cancer. Gardasil is administered to her. Which of the following statements about Gardasil is false?

choices.text: It can be administered to both males and females
It is protective against CIN and cervical cancer
It is protective against anogenital warts

questions.solution:
Gardasil is a quadrivalent vaccine against HPV 6, HPV 11, HPV 16, and HPV 18

  Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
HPV subtypes Bivalent :16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pair:
questions.solution:
The early deceleration pattern on CTG implies fetal head compression.

Following are the various types of decelerations seen on CTG and their clinical significance:

Feature Early deceleration Late deceleration Variable deceleration
Pattern of heart rate fall
  • Gradual decline and gradual recovery of heart rate   
  • Nadir of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of a contraction  
  • Symmetrical and gradual decline in heart rate
  • Onset, nadir and recovery occur after the onset, peak and recovery of contraction
  • Abrupt fall in the heart rate   
  • Onset of a deceleration varies with each contraction
Time taken to reach the nadir of deceleration > 30seconds > 30seconds < 30 seconds
Special feature   Nil    Nil Associated with shoulders of acceleration at the beginning and end of a deceleration component
Cause Fetal head compression Fetal hypoxia due to maternal hypotension, placental dysfunction and excessive uterine activity Umbilical cord compression

 

The following are the images of early, late and variable decelerations in sequence:
