Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 22 yr old woman, with a B negative blood group, is diagnosed with an ectopic pregnancy. She is treated with a multi-dose protocol of methotrexate. What is the dose of Anti D for alloimmunization in a treated case of ectopic pregnancy ______
questions.solution:
Anti D is not given when the ectopic pregnancy is corrected through medical techniques.

300 micrograms(1500IU) is the minimum dose of Anti D which is used for alloimmunization as per recent NICE guidelines.

NICE guidelines for Anti – D prophylaxis:

1. All Rh-negative women should be offered Anti - D (unless RhD negative women who have had free fetal DNA screening (cffDNA) and given a result which predicts the fetal group as negative. If such women still request Anti-D they should be offered).

First trimester indications (300 mcg)

  • Chorionic villus sampling
  • Miscarriage
  • Termination of pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy

Second-trimester & third-trimester indications (300 mcg) 

  • Amniocentesis, Cordocentesis
  • Obstetric hemorrhage
  • Abdominal trauma
  • External cephalic version

2. All Rh D-negative women should be given a single dose of 1500 units (300 mcg) of anti D between 28 - 30 weeks of pregnancy.

3. Postnatally within 72 hours (300 mcg).

4. All women who deliver Rh D-positive baby should have a quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage to guide appropriate dose of anti D prophylaxis.

questions.text: If one of the ala of the sacral bone shows arrested development, the pelvis is called :
questions.solution:
In Naegele's pelvis, there is arrested development of one ala of the sacrum.

  • Option b
    •  In Robert pelvis the ala of both the sides are absent and the sacrum is fused with the innominate bones.
  • Option c
    • In Scoliotic pelvis, the acetabulum is pushed inwards on the weight-bearing side. Oblique asymmetry of the pelvis results in contraction of one of the oblique diameters.
  • Option d
    • In Osteomalacic pelvis there is softening of the pubic bones due to deficiency of calcium and vitamin D

questions.text: A 29 year old G4P0A3 presents with headache at 28 weeks of gestation. She has a previous history of 3 spontaneous abortions in the first trimester. She also had gangrene of the big toe of the left foot for which she underwent disarticulation. She was positive for lupus antibody and anti cardiolipin antibody when evaluated at 16 weeks of gestation. She is still positive for the same. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of anti phospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA).

Clinical and laboratory criteria for diagnosis of APLA syndrome:

Clinical criteria

  • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond ten weeks, or
  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks, or
  • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks 
  • Vascular: One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

Lab criteria

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant
  • Medium or high levels of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies, or
  • Anti beta 2 glycoprotein I IgG or IgM antibody

Atleast one clinical and one lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

Lab criteria must be positive on 2 or more occassions atleast 12 weeks apart.

B2-glycoprotein I, also known as apolipoprotein H, is a phospholipid-binding plasma protein that inhibits prothrombinase activity within platelets.

This inhibits ADP-induced platelet aggregation. Thus, its normal action is to inhibit procoagulant binding and thereby prevent coagulation cascade activation. The antibodies produced against Beta2-GP1 thus triggers the coagulation cascade causing thrombus formation.

  • Tests for the diagnosis of lupus anticoagulant:
    • aPTT
    • Kaolin clotting time
    • Dilute Russel viper venom time.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding donor twin, in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS )?
questions.solution:
Donor twin is anemic in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a type of fetal syndrome that can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion.

This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic fetofetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling such that the donor may eventually become anemic and its growth may be restricted. In contrast, the recipient becomes polycythemic and may develop circulatory overload manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics
Oliguria Polyuria
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Hypotension Hypertension
Anemia Polycythemia
Renal failure Congestive cardiac failure
Growth restriction Premature rupture of membranes
Pulmonary hypoplasia Hyperbilirubinemia
Contractures  

Note: The donor twin is also known as the pump twin / stuck twin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female appeared agitated and claimed that her baby was stolen from the womb by her sister. She was seen talking to herself and has been awake for the past 4 days. Her husband reports that she has been feeling low all the time for 2 weeks. She delivered a healthy female baby 3 weeks back. What is the preferred management for her condition?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the patient is showing features of postpartum psychosis (depression with psychotic features) and the preferred management for her is initiating antipsychotics and lithium.

It can often begin within days of the delivery, although the mean time to onset is usually within 2 to 3 weeks of delivery. Characteristically, the patient begins to complain of fatigue, episodes of tearfulness and emotional lability. Later, suspiciousness, confusion, irrational statements, and obsessive concerns about the baby's health and welfare may be present. They eventually develop delusions that involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Hallucinations if present may involve voices telling the patient to harm the baby or herself. 

Management:

  • Hospitalization
  • Antipsychotics and lithium
  • Electroconvulsive therapy may be used in refractory cases

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is not used to calculate the  Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) prognostic score according to WHO?
questions.solution:
According to WHO, Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) prognostic score calculation, uses the pre-treatment serum β-hCG values.

When GTD recurs or there is evidence of metastatic disease, it is called gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) and comprises four subtypes of disease:

  • Invasive mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT)
  • An epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT)
Scores 0 1 2 4
Age (years) < 40 ≥ 40 - -
Antecedent pregnancy Mole Abortion Term  
Interval after index pregnancy (months) < 4 4–6 7–12 >12
Pretreatment serum β-hCG (mIU/mL) < 103 103 to 104 104 to 105 ≥ 105
Largest tumor size (including uterus) < 3 cm 3–4 cm ≥ 5 cm -
Site of metastases   Spleen, kidney GI Liver, brain
Number of metastases   1-4 5-8 >8
Previous failed chemotherapy drugs - - 1

>2

Low risk neoplasia has a score of 0-6. If the score is  7 or more it is classified as high risk.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with otherwise uncomplicated, unoperated atrial septal defect comes for an antenatal check-up. She belongs to WHO 2 risk category. Which among the following is the ideal management recommendation for her?

choices.text: Cardiology consultation once or twice during pregnancy

questions.solution:
As the case antenatal mother belongs to WHO 2 risk category in the WHO risk classification for cardiovascular disease in pregnancy, the ideal management for her would be cardiac consultation in each trimester.

Uncomplicated unoperated atrial septal defect, repaired Fallot's tetralogy, and most arrhythmias come under WHO 2 risk category in the WHO risk classification for cardiovascular disease in pregnancy. There is a small increase in maternal mortality and morbidity. 

The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor > 30 weeks > 22 weeks.

  • WHO 1 risk category: Risk no higher than the general population. Cardiovascular consultation once or twice during pregnancy is recommended
  • WHO 2 risk category: Small increase in maternal mortality and morbidity. Cardiac consultation in each trimester recommended
  • WHO 2 or 3: Depends on an individual case. Individualized care is recommended.
  • WHO 3 risk category: Significantly increased risk of maternal mortality. A multispeciality team is required for management.
  • WHO 4 risk category: Very high risk of maternal mortality and morbidity. Pregnancy is contraindicated and termination is discussed.

questions.text:
A primigravida was rushed to the emergency with generalized tonic-clonic seizures at 38 weeks of gestation. Her family reported her having complained of a headache and abdominal pain before the seizures. Her medical records showed that she was diagnosed with gestational hypertension at 22 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is false regarding further management of this patient?

DTR: Deep tendon reflexes
MgSO4: Magnesium sulfate

choices.text: Loading dose of MgSO4 should be reduced if urine output <30 mL/hr
Plasma magnesium levels need to be maintained at 4-7 mEq/L
Maintenance doses of MgSO4 are given only if DTRs are present
Calcium gluconate should be readily available while giving MgSO4

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of eclampsia where the loading dose of 4 g IV MgSO4 is given irrespective of renal function status.

Although magnesium is cleared almost exclusively by renal excretion, the loading dose of magnesium sulfate can be safely administered regardless of renal function. Only the maintenance dose needs to be altered according to the renal function. This is because the loading dose is responsible for reaching therapeutic levels but the maintenance doses are responsible for maintaining steady states.

Magnesium sulfate is used for the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L. (Option B)

The two regimens commonly used are Pritchard and Sibai regimens.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard)  4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minutes followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock)  5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)  4 g IV slow over 15-20 minute  1-2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes 
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)
  • Urine output (<30 ml/h)
  • Chest pain, heart block

Repeated or maintenance dose IM injections are continued only if:

  • Patellar reflex (deep tendon reflex) is present (Option C)
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV (Option D)

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Related Pearl: Tocolytic agents

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of dull aching pain in the lower abdomen for the past 8 months. There is no clinical evidence of any pelvic pathology. She says the pain decreases on lying down and increases on walking, bending, and standing. You diagnose her with having chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Which of the following is false regarding this syndrome?

choices.text: Conscious pain mapping is not useful in diagnosis

questions.solution:
Conscious pain mapping is a useful investigation in the diagnosis of chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Chronic pelvic pain (CPP) refers to acyclical pelvic pain of more than 6 months duration. 

Chronic pelvic pain syndrome is a condition characterized by CPP not associated with any clinical evidence of pelvic pathology. It possibly occurs because of dilated pelvic veins. And, hence, shifting the location of pain with body movement is characteristic of this syndrome. It is associated with congestive dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital ache, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Doppler ultrasound and venography help in the diagnosis. Conscious pain mapping at laparoscopy under local anesthesia is useful in deciding the cause and location of chronic pain. This improves diagnostic accuracy.

Treatment comprises progestogen therapy. Progestogens, by their anti-estrogenic effect, constrict the veins, reduce blood flow, and suppress ovulation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with greenish frothy vaginal discharge. On examination, she had a strawberry cervix. Which among the following statements regarding the condition is false?

Male partner should also be treated in case of recurrent infection
Wet smear with KOH shows mycelia and pseudohyphae

Wet smear in KOH shows mycelia and pseudohyphae in candida infection. The given clinical features are suggestive of trichomonas vaginitis.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida comes for a routine check-up at 30 weeks of gestation. On examination the size of the uterus is found to be more than the period of amenorrhea. On USG, AFI was 32. Which of the following could be a possible cause for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of polyhydramnios and a cleft palate in the fetus could be a possible cause for this condition.

Impaired swallowing in the fetus due to the cleft palate results in polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios is the condition where liquor amni exceeds 2000 ml. Sonographic diagnosis is made when the amniotic fluid index (AFI) is more than 24 cm and the deepest vertical pocket is more than 8 cm.

questions.text: In which of the following steps does the 1st meiotic division occur?
questions.solution:
1st meiotic division occurs in B to C i.e, in the transition from primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte.

Other options:

  • A to B - mitosis
  • C to D - 2nd meiotic division
  • D to E - spermiogenesis

questions.text: A woman presents with increasing pelvic pain and discomfort, a few days before the onset of her period. She mentions that her symptoms are rapidly relieved once the period begins. This type of dysmenorrhea is best described as:
questions.solution:
The history of increasing pelvic discomfort and pain, a few days before the onset of period, which gets relieved thereafter, is suggestive of congestive dysmenorrhea. 

Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhoea affects more than half of post-pubescent women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. It doesn't have any particular cause 
  • Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhoea is associated with the presence of organic pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis.
    Unilateral dysmenorrhoea can be seen in a rudimentary horn of the bicornuate uterus, IUCD users, and cervical stenosis.

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea is the most prevalent type characterized by cramping pain before or at the start of menstruation, especially on the first and second days of menstruation.
  • Congestive dysmenorrhoea is seen in PID, IUCD users, pelvic vein varicosities, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. These patients have increasing pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain a few days before menstruation after which they have rapid relief of the symptoms. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhoea is characterized by endometrial shedding as a cast during menses and this passage of cast leads to painful uterine cramps. It is the rarest variety.

questions.text: The following maneuver is being performed on a woman in labor. If this fails, which of the following obstetrical maneuvers is not going to be tried to aid this delivery?
questions.solution:
The image depicts McRoberts maneuver, performed in case of shoulder dystocia and so, Pinard’s maneuver ( done in cases of breech delivery), will not be tried here.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia :

  • Suprapubic pressure
  • Mc Roberts maneuver (flexion the thigh upwards towards the abdomen)
  • Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180° in a corkscrew fashion)
  • Other steps:
    • Zavanelli maneuver (replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery)
    • Cleidotomy (fracture clavicle of the baby - for the dead fetus)
  • Other maneuvers: Rubin, Gaskin (All Four's Position), Hubbard, Barnum maneuver.

 

 

The Wood's corkscrew maneuver is shown below

The image above illustrates cleidotomy being performed

Note:

In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manoeuvre.

Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: Most of the blood in the retroplacental hematoma in a non traumatic case is maternal
Feto-maternal hemorrhage can occur in traumatic cases
MRI is highly sensitive to detect this condition
Likelihood of consumptive coagulopathy is reduced with concealed hemorrhage

questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is abruptio placentae. The likelihood of consumptive coagulopathy is elevated with concealed haemorrhage in abruptio placentae.

This is because increased pressure within the intervillous space, caused by expanding retroplacental clot, forces more placental thromboplastin into the maternal circulation.

Placental abruption  

  • Premature separation of the normally implanted placenta
  • The process begins as a decidual hematoma which then expands to cause separation and compression of the adjacent placenta
  • Bleeding typically insinuates between the uterus and the membranes and ultimately escape through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage
  • When blood is retained between the detached placenta and uterus, it leads to concealed hemorrhage and delayed diagnosis.

Clinical classification of placental abruption:

Grade 1

Grade 2

Grade 3

Vaginal bleeding is slight

Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate

Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

Uterine tenderness is always present

Uterine tenderness is marked.

Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected

Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained

Shock is pronounced

FHS good

Fetal distress present

Fetal death is the rule

 Maternal shock absent

Maternal shock absent

Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who did not receive any vaccination prior to conception presented with coryza, maculopapular rash over the trunk, and fever during her first trimester of pregnancy. Following birth, the newborn presented with bilateral cataracts and a patent ductus arteriosus. What could be the possible infection that the mother suffered from?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history the diagnosis in the newborn is congenital rubella syndrome and the mother suffered from rubella infection. 

Maternal rubella is a viral infection that is subclinical in almost half of the cases. However, the mother is at risk of transmitting the virus to the fetus during the first trimester of pregnancy which causes congenital rubella syndrome in the child. The illness is usually mild and the patient presents with maculopapular rash starting on the face and progressing to the trunk and extremities. The incubation period of the infection is from 12 to 23 days. The virus is isolated upto 2 weeks after the onset of rashes in urine, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

In the fetus, the infection presents as congenital rubella syndrome and the features include bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and congenital heart disease, more commonly patent ductus arteriosus.  

Other options:

Option A: Toxoplasma infection occurs due to the consumption of uncooked meat and is characterized by muscle pain, headache and lymphadenopathy which is not present in this patient. The fetus will have a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

Option B: Parvovirus infection is characterized by erythroderma with red rashes giving an appearance of a slapped cheek. The main defect in the fetus is anemia.

Option C: Infection with varicella virus is characterized by pruritic vesicular rashes. The fetus can develop fetal varicella syndrome characterized by chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, limb hypoplasia, growth restriction, cerebral atrophy, and cicatricial skin lesions.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. The pain is restricted to the site of the fibroid. This was associated with nausea and vomiting. She also developed a fever and her WBC count was 18000/μL. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of red degeneration of the fibroid. Red degeneration in pregnancy is managed with bed rest and analgesics.

Red degeneration is a complication of fibroids that often develops during pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. It is an aseptic condition. Clinical features acute pain abdomen restricted to the site of the fibroid, fever, and vomiting. Investigations reveal an elevated WBC count and a raised ESR. Diagnosis can be made by ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with bed rest and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 23-year-old G2P1 with a previous history of Cesarean section for breech presentation presents to your clinic. Which of these factors would favor her having a successful vaginal delivery in this pregnancy?

choices.text: Low vertical incision in previous Cesarean
Induction of labor in present pregnancy

questions.solution:
Spontaneous onset of labor favors a successful vaginal birth after C-section (VBAC) among the given options in a 23-year-old G2P1 with a previous history of C-section for breech presentation.

Favorable factors for VBAC:

  • Spontaneous labor
  • Prior fetal malpresentation
  • Transverse incisions
  • Non-recurrent indication (breech,fetal distress)
  • Current preterm pregnancy
  • Teaching hospital
  • White race

Increased failure rates:

  • Single mother
  • Increased maternal age
  • Macrosomic fetus
  • Obesity
  • Breech
  • Multifetal pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • Gestational age> 40 weeks
  • Low-vertical incision
  • Labour induction
  • Multiple prior cesarean deliveries
  • Short inter-delivery interval 

Risk factors for VBAC:

Low risk  High risk
  • Transverse incision
  • Prior vaginal delivery
  • Sufficient personnel and equipment
  • Classical or T incision in prior cesarean
  • Prior Rupture
  • Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa
  • Inadequate facilities

questions.text: After crowning was established in a patient in labor, the obstetrician uses the instrument shown below to give a liberal episiotomy. By doing so, what grade of perineal injury is the obstetrician iatrogenically inflicting?
questions.solution:
The image shows an episiotomy scissor, which can be identified by its angulation. It is used to perform an episiotomy. During episiotomy, the obstetrician iatrogenically induces a second-degree perineal tear.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear that involves the perineal muscles but spares the anal sphincter. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Timely episiotomy prevents third and fourth-degree perineal tears, which affect the anal sphincter.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles
  • Fascia covering the muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

Episiotomies are either midline or mediolateral:

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: In an Rh-negative pregnancy, which of the following parameters of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) doppler is used to detect fetal anaemia?

choices.text: An increase in peak systolic velocity
A decrease in mean systolic velocity

questions.solution:
Increased peak systolic velocity in fetal MCA doppler is used to detect fetal anemia in RH negative pregnancy.

In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The velocity also increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.

If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion.
